docTitle.titlePart: Diary of a Journey undertaken in 1814 via Paris to London and various factory towns in England, with particular attention to technological aspects.

titlePage.byline: By Johann Conrad Fischer, Lieutenant Colonel of Artillery.

div.head: Fischers Interesse am technischen Fortschritt
div.p: Foreword.

Not a year and a half ago, I resolved to take a journey via Paris to London and various factory towns in England, in order, insofar as the limitations of my time permitted, to become acquainted firsthand with the progress that has been made in iron and steel production over the last twenty years since I visited the country on my return from Sweden.
Particularly favourable circumstances gave my observations a greater scope and significance than I myself believed at the outset.

Given the diversity of things I experienced there, I thought it better not to entrust everything to memory but to record all that I saw each day in writing and, so, this travel diary came into being, which I wrote in language unadorned and intended only for myself. After all, my intentions on this journey were strictly my own and for no other purpose.

After my return, however, a number of my friends were keen to learn of what I had seen on the island and, so, to comply with their wishes, I was obliged to circulate my diary both here and abroad. It was only
recently that it was returned to my possession, with the request from many that its contents, which proved not uninteresting, be made more generally known in print.

Although it is quite different to write only for oneself or one's friends, on whose indulgence one can rely, than for an audience that is entitled to stricter demands, in which respect some things would have required a more careful selection or more complete elaboration, I nevertheless prefer to leave it as it was from the beginning, with the wish that it may also be received favourably in this form. Lastly, I would like to add that,
as extraordinary as the description of one or the other object may be, especially regarding the size and extent of various manufactories, everything is based on fact, on what I saw or heard while there. I have included the exceptional things in these pages all the more gladly, so that they may serve as example and encouragement to myself of how far diligence and perseverance can take one, even in initially small enterprises.
The author.

div.head: Schaffhausen–Basel, 7. August 1814
div.p: On Sunday, August 7th, I left here for Basel in the company of my young friend Ringk von Wildenberg, who, coming from Italy, also intended to travel to London, in order to continue the following day with the courier via Belfort to Paris. However, the route had not yet been re-established since the peace, so we were forced to take the detour via Colmar and Nancy.

div.head: Basel–Paris, 8.–14. August 1814
div.p:
On the evening of the 8th, we arrived in Colmar via HüningenEin Jahr später wurde die Festung von der österreichischen Armee unter Erzherzog Johann von Österreich erstürmt und geschliffen. Johann Conrad Fischer pflegte mit dem Erzherzog Johann regelmässigen Kontakt. and Mühlhausen, without, to my surprise, being asked for our passports at the border, and on the morning of the 9th, after passing through Schlettstadt during the night, we arrived in the
commercial town of Sainte-Marie-aux-Mines, at the foot of the Vosges.

It was strange to me to hear from the local people that this vital mountain pass had never been occupied by the French in 1813 and that the first resistance had only taken place on the other side of the mountains at St. Dié or St. Diez. In the night of the 9th, or rather in the morning of the 10th at two o'clock, we arrived in Nancy, where we had the pleasure of first having to arrange lodging, as the place where the diligence stopped, having reached its destination, did not accept foreigners.

After hearing in the morning that seats in a stagecoach from Nancy to Paris would not be available for another two days, and then not with certainty, we decided, together with two French officers and a
serviceman who had served under Davoust in Hamburg, to hire a private coach, whose owner promised, and committed himself in writing, to deliver us to Paris by the afternoon of the 14th (with the same horses, of course). On the evening of the 10th at four o'clock, we left Nancy, and in Toul something happened, which we had already foreseen, namely that one of our horses had broken down and had to be left behind.

The coachman, a German, drank himself into a stupor out of vexation over it and continued by night and fog out of the gate. Seeing him in this state, I feared he might topple over and, so, joined him in the driver’s box to avert the danger. He remarked to me, however, that I may remain calm, as God never forsakes a German, that he had been in this ..... country for twelve years and had always managed to get along quite well, except that
two years ago his wife, a Parisian woman, had taken the eight hundred francs he had saved and run off with his two horses and her lover, so that now he was obliged again to work in the service of others for wages, whereas before he had been his own master. I admired his philosophical equanimity, but, nevertheless, expressed some doubt that, judging by the condition of the horses, we would be in Paris on the 14th as his master had promised. He assured me, however, that it would most certainly be done, and, indeed, we arrived at the preappointed stages on the 12th at Epernay and on the 13th at La-Ferté, albeit, not without leaving a horse behind at each night's quarters. In Epernay, we saw ample traces of those events wherein German strength conquered French arrogance and where the first generals became the first heroes.

div.head: Ankunft in Paris, 14. August 1814
div.p:
Early in the morning of the 14th, while driving, our driver suddenly sprang from the box shouting, Arrête, femme!, to run after a woman holding a handkerchief in front of her face, abandoning us to our fate and the horses to their will. The horses, however, were not at all inclined to take to their heels, and so we were able to watch at our leisure as our coachman caught up with the fugitive about four hundred paces behind the carriage, brought her back after some lively gesticulations, half voluntarily, half under duress, and introduced her to us as his runaway wife. He placed her next to him in the driver’s box with immense satisfaction. She, however, did not appear to take nearly as much pleasure in this game of chance and, probably out of delicate shyness, covered her face entirely with her husband's cloak,
as we did, in fact, enter Paris at three o'clock that afternoon. Ringk and I were happy to take leave of our present traveling party, from whom we had heard nothing but praise – first in verse, then in prose – for their former lord and master, who now resided on Elba. Incidentally, I took an interest in the fate of a French officer who we met along the way, carrying his haversack, and to whom we offered a seat in the carriage as a courtesy. According to his discharge papers, he was thirty-six years old, had thirty-two years of service (campaigns count double) and nine wounds. He had done tours of duty in Egypt, Germany, Spain and Russia and, despite all that, remained a second lieutenant. Not an educated man, but a very good soldier apparently. He complained bitterly that others had been given preferential treatment and that
he had been undeservedly disadvantaged. — I took up quarters at the Hôtel des Ambassadeurs, rue Helvetius, with which I was already familiar, and as the evening was fine, I took another walk through the Palais-Royal to the Tuileries.

div.head: Colonne Vendôme und ein Theaterbesuch, 15. August 1814
div.p:
On August 15th, on account of the Feast of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary, no one in Paris was available for business, and the shops were closed. Nevertheless, in the morning I visited Häring, an optician in the Palais-Royal, where I tested an achromatic telescope on the battlements of his house and inspected his machine for drawing the brass or plated-copper extension pipes for the tubes (when soldered together) round and straight over steel cylinders through corresponding rings, a process that facilitates the assembly of optical instruments greatly by ensuring that the axes fall into one another properly, thus, improving the concentricity of the glasses.
The machine is simple and effective, and the cylinders move vertically instead of horizontally through the rings to save space in the narrow room. The mechanism is the same as a winch, except that it is fitted with a flywheel (which moves too slowly to be of use). A chain, connected to the hook of the winch and passing over the rollers, pulls the cylinders through with the tubes placed over them.

After taking down some useful addresses from Mr. Häring's address book and buying a map and description of Paris, I set out to visit the museum. In the eleven years since I had last seen it, it had grown considerably, especially regarding the number of magnificent statues.
I estimated the number of visitors at a minimum of two thousand, yet there was no crowding in the least. There were especially many English visitors. It gave me pleasure to hear again the sound of a language that I have missed for some twenty years and that I hold in high esteem for its richness and enthusiasm. After a dreadful and expensive lunch at the Palais-Royal, I climbed to the top of the memorial column on Place Vendôme erected by Napoleon in honour of the great army for the campaign of 1805 and cast from the metal of captured cannons. Its height, including the pedestal and without the twenty-two feet high statue of the emperor, which has now been taken down, is still one hundred and eleven Parisian feet, and its weight forty thousand centners. Two hundred and seventy-six bas-reliefs provide a visual chronology of this three-month campaign, beginning with the departure from the camp at Boulogne and ending with the Battle of Austerlitz.

A lapidary-style Latin inscription above the metal door reads: The exalted Emperor Napoleon dedicated this column to the glory of the great army. It was made of the metal he seized during the German war, which ended under his leadership within three months in 1805.

Within the column, one hundred and seventyErratum aus Erstdruck. steps lead to its capital, which is surrounded by a metal gallery. A brief inscription on the dome (calotte), or cylindrical dome, with a paraboloid roof cast in a single piece, which was once the base of Napoleon's statue, states that Denon (famous for his work in Egypt) had supervised its construction, based
on the drawings of the architect Lepere.
This work, which has few equals in its purity of taste and none in its art, was begun in August 1807 and completed in August of 1810.

Not until nightfall did I descend from this remarkable monument to make my way to the Théatre des Variétés to see Brunet, who was famous and popular with the Parisian public for his calembours and witty opinions. The three pieces performed there were of little importance, and the one entitled Le Cocq was modelled entirely after Schubart's German Michel. The actors' costumes, judging from the available copperplates, were quite similar to those of Moliere's time. It was congruous with the coachmen and their oversized bagwigs, as well as
the officers in shoes and stockings, which one frequently sees nowadays, for, as it would seem, in order to please the court, everything old is once again en vogue.

div.head: Ausflug nach Chaillot, 16. August 1814
div.p: On the morning of the 16th, I went to Mr. Belon to present my letter of credit, and then to Mr. Le Page, the most famous gunsmith in Paris, to show him some drilled Stutzer and pistol barrels made of cast steel, for which he immediately placed an order. He showed me his splendid stock of weapons, among them a large number of pistols with his newly developed locks, which are fired without the use of stones and powder by means of the Muriatique oxigénée, which explodes at the mere strike of the hammer. In the depot of the Versailles arms factory, I was referred to the director of the manufactory, Mr. Bouty, at Versailles itself.

Since the peace, ser
vice to London has been restored, leaving daily at noon or in the evening at eight o'clock, so that one can reach London in four days, at the most, for the sum of one hundred and ten francs, including the cost of passage across the channel. After arranging to travel on the 18th, I left for Chaillot after lunch to show my traveling companion the steam engine there and the splendid iron foundry of Mr. Perrier, whom I already knew personally.
He was not at home. However, I learned from the secretary that, since the peace, here, as everywhere else, things were going badly for the manufactories.

The twisting of a long, thin, cylindrical iron piston rod between wooden lunettes and wedges inserted between the wooden base
and the use of crochet gave me several good ideas for handling such objects, though the fixing of the moulding sand in a six-foot-long bottle by means of iron agraffes seemed peculiar to me.

div.head: Bekanntschaft mit Philippe Gengembre, 17. August 1814
div.p:
Those who must have their passports inspected in Paris and who are not keen to travel are condemned to a great deal more walking than is customary. Such was my fate on the 17th, since Ringk had gone out before we had received our passports back from the police for further inspection at the Swiss Embassy and the Minister of the Interior, where one had to pay ten francs for each individual signature, which amounted to almost three and a half hours of walking. After finishing a transaction with a bookseller on the Quai Voltaire, I decided spontaneously to go to the mint to make the per
sonal acquaintance of the director, Mr. Gingembre. He received me somewhat coldly at first, having taken me for a traveling salesman peddling my wares. However, I immediately made it clear to him that this was not at all the case, and that I wished to make his acquaintance in a scientific matter, as he had written to me in this regard a few years henceWahrscheinlich im Zusammenhang mit dem Preisausschreiben der «Société d'Encouragement pour l'industrie nationale» von 1808/09: Fischer und Philippe Gengembre hatten damals indirekt miteinander zu tun, als Gengembre in seiner Rolle als Genralinspektor für das Geldwesen in Paris die eingereichten Stahlproben von Fischer untersuchte.. He became very polite, as a result, and in the course of the conversation himself began to ask me about the price of steel and advice on how to obtain it. In the end, I was obliged to give him a piece of cast steel from a medallion I had with me and a sample of yellow steel, the main components of which are one part copper and three parts steel, in which he took a particular interest.

As I was leaving, he begged of me to inquire in England about por
table steam engines with no condenser, as he was currently working on the production of such an engine. My plan to make known in England the weldable cast steel I had invented, as well as the thin-rolled spring steel, with a view to selling it there, he fully approved, convinced that this weldable cast steel was the ideal material for the manufacture of tools.
As I was indisposed and very tired, I limited myself to visiting a few quincaillerie and taking an order from Mr. Häring to London and concluded my day's work with a letter home.

div.head: Besichtigung der Feuerwehr und Abreise, 18. August 1814
div.p:
Having learned in passing at a station of the pompiers on the Quai des Orfevres that every morning at seven o'clock they manoeuvre with the fire engines,
I went there, though still indisposed, on the 18th. I had expected their equipment would be very good, but my illusions were shattered at first sight. The fire engines are old and dilapidated, and the good discipline and skill of the firefighters, as well as their number (there are forty stations in Paris), contribute more to the speedy extinguishing of the fire than does the efficiency of their equipment, which, by design, allows no more than eight men to operate it and sprays a jet of water scarcely eighty feet. The hoses are made of leather and, as I noticed, not lubricated, and therefore bad. I promised the commanding officer (for they are organized like the military and dressed and armed as such) to send a hundred feet of hemp hose, woven without a seam, with which he was not at all familiar and about whose reason
able price he was surprised, for a trial when I returned home. The fire engine, which used to follow the emperor on his journeys and was operated by soldiers of the guard, was in the same warehouse. It differed from the others only in novelty and in the arrangement of the carriage, which, excluding the space for the pump, which could be loaded and unloaded, still had four seats for the operators. After another trip to the police station for my passport and a terrible lunch near the Bureau des Messageries, we left Paris at one o'clock in the afternoon.

div.head: Paris–Dover, 18.–21. August 1814
div.p:
Neither our traveling party (which consisted of an ignorant Scotsman, a former sergeant in English service from Hanover, a merchant from Calais, and a woman from Paris), nor
nor the villages we passed through warrant much mention. I noticed a striking uncleanliness and poor appearance in Amiens, in contrast to which Boulogne-sur-mer stood out quite favourably, be it on account of its proximity to England and the intercourse with that island or the fact that, in general, the seaside towns of the North Sea and the canal tend to be considerably cleaner.

Having travelled day and night, we arrived at Amiens on the 19th in the morning, at Boulogne on the 20th, and by ten o'clock that same morning at Calais, near which, in the little village of Huit-mille (so I was told the orthography of that name), was located the stone tomb of the ill-fated aviator Pilatre du Rozier and his companions not far from the road where they crashed.

Despite all earlier inconveniences with our passports, we were still made
to pay three francs and fifty centimes in Calais for permission to embark. The embarkation itself took place in the afternoon at three o'clock on the parcel ship Espérance, Capitain Benoit. There must have been some fifty passengers aboard, many of them women. The wind was quite unfavourable, becoming fierce towards evening, and the sea was very rough. This and the frequent tacking of the sails, which caused the ship to sway in the opposite direction, soon caused a generalized seasickness. Revulsion soon aroused it in me, as well. I lay down on the deck, lamentably covered (because of the rain) with a piece of wet sailcloth that my unfortunate companions snatched from me from time to time, and I did not get up again until we disembarked in Dower at three o'clock on the morning of the 21st, after a twelve-hour crossing.

div.head: Dover–London, 21./22. August 1814
div.p:
And so, on August 21st, after twenty long years, I set foot once again on English soil! This time, too, under auspicious circumstances: “Hope” was the name of the ship that brought me there and “blessed one” (Benoit) the name of its captain. — My most urgent business, upon entering the "Paris-Hotel" (English name of the inn), was to refresh myself again with an English beer, which was to be followed by a tea, so that I might sleep soundly, something that these two medicines accomplished perfectly. As the journey was to continue to London on the afternoon of Sunday, the 21st, the suitcases had to be inspected first. This presented some degree of difficulty, as one does not gladly conduct business on a Sunday in England. However, this was nothing that a payment of four shillings to the customs officer
could not resolve, and at five o'clock in the evening we departed for London via Canterbury and Rochester in a stagecoach, whose elegance and design would not have disgraced any emissary and arrived at Woodstreet-Cheapside at five o'clock on the morning of the 22nd. We had covered this distance of seventy-two English miles in ten hours, stopping for a full two hours at various places along the way. One must behold the beauty and speed of the horses to fully appreciate it (sixty guineas and above is the going rate for each of them), but even more so the splendour of the countryside and the towns and villages from Dover to London. Such a vision of wealth and prosperity is not to be found anywhere else, and it is no wonder that the French were en
vious of it, for the disparity between this and that country is, indeed, striking.

The careful, garden-like arrangement of the most extensive hop fields and the splendid sheep farms, where the health and comfort of these animals is assured in every way, demonstrate the amount of attention paid by the English to everything that can bring about the improvement and perfection of anything. Despite my twenty-year absence, I managed to find my way around London. I cannot say that much has improved, and I noticed just as little progress regarding products and stores. Only everything has become tremendously expensive, and some things, including the basic necessities of life, have risen by twenty to fifty percent. I have not yet been able to ascertain the actual reason for this increase.
Perhaps nobody was willing to tell me. However, the effect of the Napoleonic interdict may have contributed indirectly, and the total disappearance of gold, which was once so common, and which has now been replaced only by paper, may also have contributed more directly. The pressure of the times on trade and manufacturing has also been felt strongly by the English, by their own admission, though they now hope the situation will soon improve.

Having nothing more pressing to do than to make my introductions and renew my acquaintance with Mr. Y. B. Banker of London, I had the opportunity to explore London and discover stores where I might buy a few things. With a visit, which we received late in the evening from Mr. Schenk in our apartment, and the dis
patch of a letter home, this day came to a close, in which I had learned a number of things I had wished to know, among which I especially count the prices of cast steel, postage-paid from London at 1 shilling to 1 shilling 8 pence, and the circumstance that, in the whole of England, there are supposed to be no more than three cast steel manufacturersDie drei Fischer bekannten englischen Gussstahlproduzenten waren Huntsman in Attercliffe, Walker & Booth in Rotherham und P. et C. in Birmingham. and that the production of steel continues to be treated as a secret. I also had the opportunity to become acquainted with the extremely useful, and for the innkeepers immensely beneficial, device for pumping beverages out of the cellar at a single push of a button and filling the glass directly, and to make a sketch of it.

div.head: British Museum, Bleistifte und Shakespeare, 23. August 1814
div.p:
On the morning of the 23rd, after visiting several stores, I had a long and interesting conversation with a highly reputed
gunsmith of London, Mr. Morris in Ludgate-Hill, during which he firmly maintained, from his own experience regarding the characteristics of a rifled barrel, that the most accurate shot is always obtained by machining the entire length of the barrel. He completely rejected the new method of firing with Muriatique oxigénée, for, as he said, the corrosive properties of this powder also damage the inside of the barrel, rendering it unusable in a short time. He sells very strong and fine gunpowder that is neither uniformly large nor round. I arranged with him to test it against the powder from Bern I had brought with me to England. For he would not yield in his belief that the perfect roundness and uniformity of the grains contributed anything to its quality. On the contrary, he held that the powder containing angular and pointed grains
ignited more quickly everywhere due to the multiple points of contact. This rather far-fetched reasoning, I thought, only stands to show that there is something to be said for everything.

From Mr. Morris, I proceeded with RingkErratum aus Erstdruck. to the British Museum to visit Mr. Planta, whom I was fortunate enough to find there, as he customarily spends his summers in the country. I informed him of Professor Müller's letter to me and inquired about Boone. He was unable to give me any news of him but promised to make inquiries. He took the liveliest interest in the fate of the noble Johannes von Müller, who now lives on in his writings, and remarked that his history of the world would soon be translated into English.

Mr. Planta was kind enough to open
the museum at my request. However, space does not permit me to give even the briefest of accounts of it here. I only note that it has taken on a completely altered and far more advantageous design in the last twenty years. Many older objects have been altogether removed, and everything has been better and more systematically arranged. An exquisite mineral cabinet of mainly selected specimens, with Hauy’s and Werner’s classifications, has been added, and what is available of antique busts, bas-reliefs and figures has been displayed in beautiful galleries. The greatest curiosities in antiquarian terms are undoubtedly the artefacts excavated and found in Egypt and then in Herculaneum, among which the celebrated Isis tablet most captivated my attention. It is, as far as I know, the only existing monument on which the same object is described in hieroglyphics, as well as the Coptic and Greek languages.

After leaving the museum, I visited the best-known pencil manufactory in London, Brokman et Langdon, Great-Russel-Street, Bloomsbury-Square, after having previously made the acquaintance of J. Middleton et Comp. in Shoe-Lane, Fleet-StreetDas «Post Office Annual Directory» von London des Jahres 1814 führt als Adresse auf: Vine Street, Piccadilly., whose work is somewhat more refined. As I had the opportunity to watch the production of pencils in both places, I was convinced that their excellent quality depends solely on the attributes of the mineral, which can only be found in Cornwallis and is carefully selected for its greater or lesser hardness.

A journey of several miles brought me to Messrs. Bouvie et Antrobus, and from there to Mr. Huber in Green-Street, Grosvenor-Square, whom I should have liked to see before his departure. The hope of welcoming him and his honourable wife in Switzerland
diminished to some extent the uneasy feeling of having to do without the company of this gentleman, who could have been so interesting and advantageous to me during my stay in England.

At six o'clock in the evening I found myself at the home of Mr. Yeates Brown, Manchester-Street, Manchester-Square, following the invitation I had accepted to dine with him. I was received by him and his wife with the friendship that is accorded to close acquaintances in England, an affection of which I was to receive further confirmation. The splendour prevailing in the house gave clear indication of the wealth of its owner. The sitting room contained a type of low sofa, in addition to the armchairs, in oriental style, all of them covered with precious embroidered taffeta, and all the furnishings were of the most exquisite, flamed acajou, or "Mahogany".

The bay window facing the garden featured gothic windows adorned with stained glass. The silver and crystal tableware were equally as precious as the rest, the wines even more so. Among them, the Madeira was especially exquisite.

After the meal and during the tea, which took place at about ten o'clock, Mr. Brown showed me several splendid works from his precious library. As a rarity, he owned a copy of the famous OneErratum aus Erstdruck. hundred merry tales of Shakespeare, which had been lost and recently rediscovered by chance. Owing to the peculiarities inherent in the English, only fifty copies of it had ever been printed. While leafing through the book, it struck me that I recognized at once the first three or four tales, and I remembered having read them as a boy
in a very old German book, printed by a certain Hofmann, bound together with Aesop's Fables, and the whole decorated with woodcuts. It would, perhaps, not be unimportant for the philologist to know whether the English or the German edition holds the right of precedence.

As I was leaving, Mr. Brown was kind enough to invite me to his office for the following day, to furnish me with letters of introduction that would be useful to me on my forthcoming visit to the north of England.

div.head: Registrierung im Alien Office und Regenprogramm, 24. August 1814
div.p:
On the morning of the 24th, my first order of business was to go to the Alien Office, Crown-Street, Westminster, to have my passport controlled. Here, as everywhere, I have noticed far more civility towards strangers than twenty years ago, especially as regards re
primands for taking the wrong or unusual way.

As an extremely heavy rain, which lasted all day without interruption, prevented me from making any further excursions, I limited myself to collecting the letters of introduction from Mr. Brown et Siordet, visited the eminent optician DollondErratum aus Erstdruck., the tool and steel merchant Fenn in Newgate-Street, and the cuttler Stammers in the Strand, who makes steel dessert knives plated with silver on both sides, which gives them a fine, durable edge without the blades tarnishing or rusting.

As anecdote and final story of the day, I include an account of an incident concerning a young man from Boulogne-sur-mer, who had entrusted himself to unknown persons and,
thus, within the first hours of his stay in London was robbed of all his belongings down to the last coin. Since he did not understand a word of English, I was able to assist him as an interpreter to the extent that he will be able stay in one place (White-Bear, Picadilly) until he can be provided with necessities again from home. Want of time does not permit me to tell this somewhat rambling story in its entirety, now, however, it ought to find its place elsewhere for the purpose of instruction.

div.head: Geschäftsgänge in Cheapside und an der Strand, 25. August 1814
div.p:
On the morning of the 25th, assuming that I would be able to travel in the evening with one of the numerous stagecoaches leaving daily for Birmingham, I conducted some minor business with Dollond, , with whom I discussed, among other things, the mirror compositions of Short and Herschel, and
the various refractive properties of the Crown and Flint glasses. He was, or at least seemed to be, of the same opinion as I, that iron substituted for copper, under appropriate control of the melting process, should give the mirror greater lustre and whiter colour, since, as is well known, tin combines with iron equally as well as with copper, and arsenic can be entirely omitted from the mixture.

At two o'clock in the afternoon, Mr. S., who had shown my traveling companion and me considerable friendship during our stay here, collected us from our apartment to lunch with him at the Queens-Arms, Cheap-side. Before that, he was kind enough to take me to five different places from which stagecoaches depart for Birmingham, so that I might
reserve a seat; however, all the seats were already taken, and so, for two pounds sterling, I arranged to depart on the following day at four o'clock in the evening.

In passing by a crucible dealer, J. Tringham No. 3, Cary-Lane, Foster-Lane, Cheapside, into whose store I entered, it was my distinct pleasure to discern that the English black crucibles corresponded perfectly in their ratio of capacity to height, width, and thickness with my own, the form of which I had ascertained to be quite different from the German. As to the price of these crucibles, I found it very high, namely two pence per Mark, or about thirty-two Kreuzer of our money for a six-mark crucible, for which we pay fifteen Kreuzer. After dinner we went to the
Strand to visit Mr. Berola, a watchmaker, with whom I would have liked to make my acquaintance, but he was not at home. I gave two razor knives from Kym in Berlingen, which he had made for me from my steel, which at that time (nine years ago) I only made in very small quantities, to a cutler who lived next door for sharpening and polishing, with the request that he do the work himself, so that he could give me his opinion about the quality of the knives and the steel.

That same evening, I discovered an important lathe and tool factory in Cockspur-Street No. 10, Charing-Cross, whose owners, Holzapfel and DeyerleinErratum aus Erstdruck., are Germans. — Mr. Holzapfel was very obliging. He showed me his stock of lathes, the least of which cost thirty guineas, and the most beautiful, with basset
tool and guilloché machine, two hundred and fifty. Not only did I have the opportunity to admire the beauty of the workmanship thereon, but I also saw two entirely new devices, as simple as they are useful, for turning screw threads or hollow objects with the greatest of ease, the more detailed explanation of which, however, necessitates a drawing, which I will append to my notes on this subject.Die Zeichnung ist nicht überliefert.

It was still too early to see the gas lights of Pall-Mall. So, in advance of our visit, we passed by the large Wedgwood tableware factory, near St. James-Square before returning home, where Mr. S. joined us for tea, in the English manner, until ten o'clock in the evening.

div.head: Gewalzter Federstahl aus Schaffhausen, 26. August 1814
div.p:
On the morning of the 27thEs war der 26. August 1814., after I had already
made an early and futile trip to Snow-Hill to look at a home brewing apparatusErratum aus Erstdruck. that was thought to be there, but which is now in Picadilly together with its inventor, I set off to Mr. Berola with the rolled steel for watch springs that I had brought with me to London. He was very pleased with it, and after we had collected the Berlinger razor knives, which received a very favourable review from Mr. Stammers, we proceeded to Berola's watch spring maker to show him the rolled steel as well. Like most Englishmen, he was at first sceptical of anything foreign. However, when I pointed out to him the advantages of the steel, as well as the laborious, one might even say nonsensical, way in which watch springs are made in England, namely cutting them by hand from thin, cast
steel wire – the purchase price of which is six shillings and eight pence – and in such a way that each spring must be annealed six or seven before it is thin enough, he began to think better of it until, finally, he became so interested that he promised Mr. Berola to start working on springs made of this rolled steel that same day.

On the way home, I called on the watchmaker's tool dealer, Fenn in New-gate-Street who, quite enthusiastic about the rolled steel leaves for watch springs I showed to him, as well, confessed that there were none like them in all of England. I would add, the relatively high price of pocket watch springs is evidence of their laborious production in England, where a single spring costs almost as much as a dozen of the same quality in Locle or Fleurier,
i.e. half a crown. — As I was due at At the swan with two necks Inn (that was the actual name of the place) by four o'clock, from where the coach to Birmingham departs, I only had enough time to have lunch and pack the most necessary things. Mr. Ringk and Mr. S. were good enough to accompany me there, and I recommended my friend to the latter during my absence.

div.head: London–Birmingham, 26./27. August 1814
div.p:
My traveling companions in the carriage interior (the exterior or bonnet was already graced with nine passengers) included: a type founder from London, an apothecary from London, and a "Gentleman-Farmer" from the York region, who, in spite of the fine handkerchief adorning his frock coat and his silver-plated, Spanish cane walking stick, would, whenever necessary, blow his nose into his fingers
in the coach, before retrieving the rest with his handkerchief. That this impropriety was perpetrated by a farmer, who by no means appeared to be a commoner, astonished me, indeed. To my even greater astonishment, however, no one reproached him for it. — As I seemed to gratify the company by engaging in their conversation, I was treated to a tale by the type founder about the ancient history of St. Albans, the town through which we were passing, that the houses had been there since the time of Julius Caesar, which age, judging by their frailty, I would not dispute.

As the post coaches travel with extraordinary speed to this part of England (they cover eight to nine English miles in an hour, but elsewhere only seven to eight and a half), we arrived quite early in Coventry a not
insignificant and seemingly quite pretty city, and reached Birmingham on the morning of the 27th.

div.head: Birminghams «Altäre des Vulkans», 27. August 1814
div.p: Anyone repelled by the coal steam and thick air of London need not venture to Birmingham. For the extraordinary number of foundries, weapon and blade manufactories, smelting and glass furnaces, steam engines and hammer mills, wire drawing and sheet metal factories, among so many other altars to Vulcan, this city, which is said to have one hundred and thirty thousand inhabitants, is enveloped in a dense cloud of smoke, lasting on average an hour, out of which only the tops of the towers and the high chimneys of the glass and smelting furnaces are visible.

Immediately upon arrival, I proceeded to Mr. H—Herr H. ist möglicherweise Herr Hobday., to whom I had been introduced by B — et RWer hinter dieser Abkürzung steht, ist nicht bekannt.. As he himself owns a shop
filled with the various wares of Birmingham, I was unable to learn from him the names of their actual manufacturers, and as Saturday is the day the English call "a busy day", I promised to return on Monday. In passing, he showed me, among other precious commodities, a completely steel writing instrument costing fifty guineas, of which the Queen had recently had a similar one made. — Uncertain whether I would be welcomed by Messrs. Boulton et Watt with my letter of introduction from Mr. Brown on this business day in Soho, I resolved, nevertheless, to go there, so as not to lose any time and simply to ask when it would be convenient for me to visit. This very significant manufactory is located four miles from Birmingham, and its owners have generated a profit of many millions of pounds sterling for their country through their extremely sensible im
provements of the steam engine. For it was from the same epoch, the seventies and eighties of the last century, that the great boom of England's manufacturing industry dates, when Messrs. Boulton et Watt showed how their machines could be applied with safety and ease to almost every end of human art.

Mr. Watt received me very politely in the factory's counting room, after seeing the signature on my letter of introduction. I immediately remarked to him, however, that because I understood the nature of business on Saturdays in England, I wanted only to request half an hour of his time to speak with him on another day. — "If it is convenient for you," he said, "come and lunch with me tomorrow;
— then we can converse at leisure." I accepted the invitation without further ado and took my leave. I must attribute this unexpected courtesy more to the signature than to the contents of Mr. Brown's letter of introduction; for not only were the signatures in duplicate and two distinctive hands but embellished with a special emblem. All the same, I am no more likely to see the factory than any other. For I have already been informed by Mr. Brown: "He shows it to no one and has already refused to do so even to highly distinguished persons." Still, a conversation with such a man is alone worth the journey from London to Birmingham.

After lunch, I wandered through nearly the whole of Birmingham and would like to have entered ten places instead of just one, had it not
been for the commanding "Non admittance" signs posted everywhere. Through the broken windowpanes of a weapons factory (which, I say in passing, is disgracefully common to most factories here, that they have not a single good window) I observed the honing of the gun barrels and admired the skill and uniformity with which the worker let them revolve in his hands, as they were honed crosswise and not lengthwise. Three steam engines supply power to this factory for the execution of its many types of operations.

I would also have liked to see the extensive wire drawing factory, where iron and steel wire was drawn; however, as with most factories, it was walled off like a monastery. Late in the evening, I chanced to see in an open English
refining forge, what they call "Puddling-Furnaces", the very peculiar operation of refining with flame fire. The process is already known but quite interesting, as the flame from simple coals nevertheless yields relatively good iron. The lumps of thirty to forty pounds were hammered out by a very weak (since it had no counterblow) T-hammer from the family of picks in three heatings to short bars, six lines thick and four and a half lines wide. I found the method of removing the lumps from the furnace using a thin iron rod, which was inserted and immediately welded in place, very effective, as one does not require tongs and is more a master of the iron in this process, able to draw the lumps uniformly from back to front without having to turn or hammer them.
The hammer, weighing about six centners, was not lifted from the side by the handle, as in Germany, but by a cast protrusion on its head. As much as I had to acknowledge, at least in this case, the superiority of the German hammersmiths in skill and strength, I also admired the sensible arrangement of the factory, which fits into the space of one of our ordinary living rooms.

div.head: James Watt führt durch sein Werk und lädt ein zum Mittagessen, 28. August 1814
div.p:
Sunday, August 28th. A certain tribune of the people of the noble town of Schaffhausen once was meant to make a great speech, whose title he had forgot, until, at last, he exclaimed quizzically: "What matter shall I speak to, worthy and trustedErratum aus Erstdruck. fellows, what matter, now?" As no one could tell him, however,
he seized his hat and cane in exasperation and took his leave. — I find myself presently in almost the same position as this honourable gentleman in recording the events of this day, as few have had such a wealth of interesting subjects and, in view of the limited time and the importance of the matter, even I am nearly at a loss as to where to begin.

At two o'clock in the afternoon, after I had spent the morning writing, I left Birmingham for Soho, a good hour's walk away. Mr. Watt's residence, situated in a beautiful and very extensive park, is already distinguished by its construction and by the fact that it is entirely coveredErratum aus Erstdruck. with slate and built of hewn stone, while most other houses in Birmingham and other places in England are constructed of simple red
bricks. The interior, however, displays all the comforts of English life and attests to the wealth of its owner. A servant showed me to the sitting room, into which Mr. Watt entered immediately.

As Mr. Brown’s letter had introduced me to him as the director of our iron mines, the conversation turned immediately to this subject. Wishing to know the location of the mines and their strike, Mr. Watt produced a very beautiful Wyssian map of the Canton of Schaffhausen, on which I complied satisfactorily with his request. After this, the discussion turned to the various types of iron and steam engines. Quite contrary to my expectations, he led me to the part of his factory
in Soho devoted to this matter. I was amazed at what I saw there. Any description of it would be inadequate, for it escapes the powers of imagination. I shall merely note that the sheer mass of available iron alone is immense, not to mention the amount of work put into it. Things that have never been done before are accomplished here, and the erstwhile amorphous compilation of tubes and cylinders we call steam engines is here transformed into an elegant iron structure with columns of Doric and Corynthian order. After viewing a collection of Swedish, Siberian, and English iron, we were joined by Mr. Watt's associate, Mr. Boulton, for a visit to the lathe and forging workshops.

While admiring the exceptionally beautiful, hand-forged craftsmanship in the workshops, I also noticed something seemingly insignificant, but nevertheless
quite useful. The caulking and grooving chisels were attached to handles made of hazel rods by being bound together with wire wrapped all the way around them. As a result, there was no need to make a hole in the tool in order to insert the handle, meaning they are much more resistant to breakage and never bounce in the hand. A large stock of copy milling machines, which they showed me in a storeroom next to the counting room, demonstrated again the meticulousness applied to all operations here.

The conversation at the table, which, in accordance with English custom, was abundantly furnished with expensive wines, became very lively, for they seemed to take pleasure in the fact that I spoke English fluently, which Mr. Brown also remarked in all his letters of introduction, and to which, so it ap
peared to me, they attached great importance. When the conversation turned to the metal compositions of the ancients, I could hardly avoid mentioning my discovery of yellow steel. This seemed to be of interest to them, for when I showed them a sample of it, they immediately asked a certain Murdoch to join us for tea, of whom they remarkedErratum aus Erstdruck. that he had an excellent knowledge of metallurgy and had also worked on this subject for a considerable time. — The dessert, which by English standards was unusually varied, contained, among other things, splendid muscat and other grape varieties with berries the size of walnuts, the price of which per cluster is never less than half, more often an entire, guinea.

Over tea, with which coffee was served simultaneously, we conversed at length about the metal composition at hand, and Mr. Murdoch proved himself, indeed, to be a
most experienced metallurgist. However, he had never succeeded in combining anything more than one part copper with one part iron. At the mention of a large iron works in the vicinity, Mr. Watt said to me: “Mr. Fischer, you can take a bed for the night here, and, presuming you ride, we will visit some of the most interesting factories tomorrow, among others one that employs five thousand workers.” I accepted the invitation with pleasure but, for fear of appearing immodest, declined to spend the night in Soho. After taking my leave, whereby Mr. Watt accompanied me to the gates of the park, I departed for home at half past nine, fully preoccupied with my thoughts on how far diligence, intellect and perseverance can take a man.

div.head: Erkundungsritt durch das Black Country mit James Watt, 29. August 1814
div.p:
The following day, I was already in Soho at half past seven in the morning, after
having ordered alphabets and stamps of cast steel from Mr. Hobday in Legg-Street and covering five English miles on foot.

While at breakfast, a certain Mr. Low from Trinidad arrived, who ordered a steam engine of fifteen horsepower, which was to be dispatched with the October fleet. This Mr. Low spoke of the strange sea of misfortune on Trinidad, about which I had read a more detailed account in a recently published travelogue, given to me by Mr. Watt. Mr. Low left us before long, heading for the foundry and steam engine manufactory to make further arrangements with Mr. Murdoch. — "Come," said Mr. Watt shortly thereafter, "I am never certain that people will wish to speak to me," and we immediately alighted on horseback, accompanied by a groom and
a Great DaneErratum aus Erstdruck.. The horses were excellent runners. Mine was called "Jack," that of Mr. Watt "John," and the dog was called "Daniel," after the old gardener of the house.

After riding for nearly a mile, Mr. Watt stopped suddenly and said, "Where I am about to take you, no foreigner has ever gone before. I therefore implore you not to tell anyone in England, not even Mr. Brown, about this, nor should you write letters or make recommendations to me in this regard, as it would be of no use." — Soon thereafter, we dismounted at a large gateway, after having ridden through a long lane of charming and uniformly built houses, which were all workers' dwellings, each with its own garden.

This factory, which the Grand Duchess CatherineDie Grossfürstin Katharina besuchte nur wenige Monate früher im Januar 1814 mit ihrem Bruder, dem Zaren Alexander I., Fischers Werkstätte in Schaffhausen., who was as intellectual as she was knowledgeable, considered sufficiently significant during her stay in England as to honour it with an official visit, and to have it shown to her in its entirety by Mr. Watt, with whom she discussed (which he noted with particular pleasure) all of its interesting objects, but especially its steam engines, which are so varied in their construction and application. — This factory is located on the Birmingham Canal, which connects to the four main ports of England, namely Hull, Portsmuth, London and Liverpool. It is surrounded by a high wall and consists of numerous buildings, each several hundred feet in length, among which the foundry, the prototype works and
the new workshops are most remarkable. Four furnaces yield enough molten iron to make castings up to a weight of two hundred centners in a single piece. Opposite these are the drying kilns, and the ground between the two quite hollow to mould and cast the largest cylinders aright. The casting sand, which is somewhat ferruginous and contains a great deal of mica, is excavated right there on site. Indeed, the whole of Birmingham is erected on this same sand. By my estimates, the other buildings, especially the iron building — I refer to it as such for the floor, stairs and roof are made entirely of cast iron, and the floors and stairs, for that matter, are not smooth, but finely checked like carpets, painted with black paint and kept extremely clean —accommodate working steam engines ranging from six to
fifty "Horsepowers," which quietly and uniformly perform the work they were so brilliantly designed to carry out: Stamping money, rolling sheet metal, punching plated tools, moving hammers, turning enormous piston rods and spiral beams, and boring out cylinders (a single one of which often takes several months to complete). Thus, they produce more machines of their kind, and much more. Of the dozens of “Boilers” standing around, which are made of two to three layers of thick sheet iron and are excellently riveted together, I noticed that instead of the usual spherical shape, they are now parallel-epipedal with a convex top. All of the workshops, as well as the large open area, are illuminated by gas. Mr. Watt was gracious enough to
show me this lighting system, which was introduced by Mr. Murdoch. The charring, or more precisely, the distillation of the coal takes place in two large furnaces, and in large vessels next to them, the distillation of the gas, bitumen, and so on. The gas is conveyed from there into a special building with two iron tanks, which stand in water and are open at the bottom and closed at the top, holding about three thousand cubic feet. From there, it is conducted through pipes into all the buildings of the factory.

In order to illustrate the effect, Mr. Watt closed the chamber, so that gas burned, with a shining flame and completely odourless, in the glass cylinders of four-armed lamps mounted on the lectern. It remains a secret how to remove the foul odour and the bluish light of the flame from gas. I, however, was able to learn about the procedure.

From the factory, we proceeded to the neighbouring town of Smethwik to see a steam engine with a thirty-three-inch cylinder, which supplies a part of the canals with essential water. From Smethwik, our tour took us to Bilston, on the great highway to Irland, passing Capon-Fields, a very curious point, which is the place where the Birmingham canal system begins. At the highest point of the whole area, near the shaft of an abandoned water-rich coal mine are two steam engines with fifty-four-inch-wide cylinders, that deliver forty-eight cylindrical feet of water every minute, or double that, if necessary. These supply a large basin from which the deeper channels draw as much water as continuous use requires. The machines are built by Mr. Watt,
and, like all those that originate from him, are especially beautiful. From Capon-Fields across Bilston, Wednesbury, Dudley and Level-Iron-works extends not exactly a valley, but a basin some ten English miles long and four, at times six miles wide, quite unique in its kind.

The land, which is on its surface very barren, but which in its bowels contains an immeasurable wealth of limestone, iron ore and coal, is littered with buildings, particularly ironworks, steam engines, glass furnaces, soap boilers, etc., such that more than five hundred factories can be counted in this district. In the middle of it lies the great Wilkinson's Bradley Iron Works, which employs five thousand workers of the male sex alone, stands out like a crown, and is now, following the death of Mr.
Wilkinson (who, according to his wishes, was laid in a cast iron coffin, over the vault of which is still erected an iron pyramid weighing four hundred centners), run by a certain Mr. Ferryday, who in his early youth was a common coal boy.

After we had seen in various places, and only in passing, the very distinct manner in which English iron is manufactured and processed, we set out for the little town of Dudley to have lunch there (it was already three o'clock) upon our return from Level-Iron-works, which we had yet to visit, and which is three English miles from there. When we arrived at the marketplace, there was a crowd of people, and in the middle of it a huge fire with which the city’s beloved youth proved especially occupied. Upon inquiry,
we were told that a butcher had been selling bad meat, which the magistrate, after notice had been given, had taken away and handed over to the disposition of the thronging public of Dudley. The latter now consigned the corpus delicti to the fire, not at all to the edification of its seller.

When we arrived at Level-Iron-works, the owner, Mr. Gibbon, not only received us very courteously, but proceeded to show and explain to me all that I wished to know. A somewhat detailed description will be all the more appropriate here, as the mode of operation is roughly the same at all English ironworks, where the ore is smelted with cokes, and the resulting cast iron refined with coal flame. Three blast furnaces placed side by side, forty-two shaft deep, each yielding from seventy to one hundred
tons or more of iron weekly (which together amounts to six thousand centners), blow through a single cylinder nine feet in diameter and with a nine-foot piston stroke, which is set in motion by a fifty-horsepower steam engine. Since the cylinder, which delivers its blow into a large iron water regulator, is closed at the top and bottom for double the effect, the amount of air squeezed out per minute is fourteen pistons \frac{9^2\times785\times914\times2^1}{1000} = 15,866 cubic feet. This amount of air is not only sufficient for the three blast furnaces, but also supplies three “Refining furnaces,” what we would call an re-melting furnace (one cannot call it a fresh firing). Each of them has three steamers, which incline very steeply, almost like the Catalan furnaces, over which a gentle stream of water is conducted into the fire to form hydrogen
gas in order to extract the sulphur from the iron due its greater elective affinity, thus rendering the iron more suitable for refining. Over the iron, which is extracted each time in two-inch thick plates weighing up to twenty centners, water is run until it cools down completely. It is then broken into pieces of thirty to forty pounds, which are white along the broken edges and have the appearance of mock steel. Two hundred pounds of this iron at a time are then put into the "Puddling-Furnace", which I would rather call a refining furnace. For, by its nature, it is a reverberatory furnace with a flaming fire, equipped with a chimney about thirty feet high to effect a powerful pull. At the top, the chimney is opened or closed with a lid, as required. The iron, quickly liquefied by the intensity of the fire, is stir
red by the ingress of the external air through the open door of the furnace until it separates, then reconstituted, heated anew, stirred again, sprinkled with a small amount of water and, finally, divided into six lumps inside the furnace itself while in a dough-like state, these lumps, after being subjected to the heat and draught of the external air for some time, are taken out one by one and put under the large hammer. This hammer, cast in one piece with handle and grip and weighing about twelve to fifteen centners, has neither a ram nor a hammer-seat. Its two ellipsoidal arms, which are integrally cast in place of socketed heads, are supported by only two iron trestles. It is, as already explained in an earlier description, lifted at the front at the head by a steam engine, and its shape is also a T
with a surface running along the crosspiece, but lower or deeper than the rest of the channel, so that, even if it falls entirely onto the anvil, there always remains a hollow space of about four inches, in which the lump, which would shatter if the hammer were to strike fully, is first formed and compressed into a short bar. There is also another reason for this space, since the hammer has a strike area of only five inches and the lump can be up to eight inches thick and could, thus, not otherwise be placed beneath the hammer. Once the lump is compressed from four and a half inches to one and a half to an oblong piece, it is called a "Bloom" and then put into the "Bloomery", or stretching and welding furnace, which is also a very effective reverberatory furnace. Here, several pieces are
welded together when large, heavy bars are required, or the individual pieces are welded together to a whole, and then brought under the rolling and cutting mills, where square, round, or flat bars are formed in the gradually diminishing grooves, as the cutting mill delivers, in an instant, a bundle of bars anywhere from nine to two rows square, as required. Only by means of these mechanisms, which work together in such a way that there is absolutely no loss of time, is it possible to sell the resulting small iron for twelve shillings a centner, despite the high wages in England, which amount to fifteen shillings or eight guilders a week for the very lowest manual labourer, and sixteen to twenty guilders for most laborers. Not only is English
iron very affordable, but through strenuous efforts, which often make incredible things possible, it has become exceptionally good, as well – and this since the time when the war some years ago, now, albeit of short duration, between Sweden and Russia closed the English markets to the iron of Dannemora and Siberia.

Quite satisfied and with the clearest idea of the process and the ovens and machines employed, I left this home of Vulcan. Between the hundreds of charcoal piles, where the coals are turned into cokes , between coal mines with their deep shafts, and even past a district where millions of centners of self-ignited coals have burned for years, making their existence known at night with their blue flames,
like lonely spirits shining through the crevices of their crypts, we rode along back to Dudley, where beef steak and delicious ale soon made us forget the hardships of our continuous twenty-four-English-mile journey on horseback, some of which were covered at a gallop.

Our familiar conversation over dinner and the remedying of some technical matters made our time so brief that we had to make haste to catch a view of the surrounding country from the height of the beautiful ruins of Dudley-Castle , where the rays of the sinking sun made a most remarkable contrast with the clouds of smoke from the furnaces, which formed a stormy sky of their own, extending over several hours in diameter. — We also managed to climb down into Dudley's limestone quarry to see the mouth of the canal, carved three miles underground and largely through rock, that exits on the other
side of the mountain. The phenomenon, extremely curious and extremely rare to the geologist, of the exact opposite stratification of the limestone deposit on the southeast and northwest sides of this hill, and of the basalt occurring in it, merit a more extensive discussion than space permits here.

On the way home, we stopped for tea at the home of Mr. Priestley, son of the famous Doctor Priestley. He is considering the idea of powering carriages in America, where he will soon return, with steam engines instead of horses, which is already being done successfully in England near Leeds. After riding another four miles, we arrived in Soho around midnight, illuminated by more than one and a half hundred flames blazing from the chimneys of the smelting furnaces. After
sharing an idea with Mr. Watt, of which I will speak again later, I continued to Birmingham, and in the morning between one and two o'clock, well satisfied with the fruits of this day, I retired to bed.

div.head: Erste Begegnung mit dem Temperguss in Birmingham, 30. August 1814
div.p:
The 30th marked my first visit to Soho, to bid farewell to Mr. Watt and, at the same time, to obtain from Mr. Murdoch a piece of platinum wire, which he melts down by the pound and sells at fifteen shillings an ounce, for lining the touch holes of rifles. In addition to the friendship he has already shown me, Mr. Watt was kind enough to provide me with a letter of introduction to Mr. Lee, owner of the largest spinning mill in Manchester (which is also remarkable for the gas lighting introduced there), as well as another letter similar in kind to the famous Wedgwood, whose factory in New-Etruria near Newcastle-under-Lide was not far out
of my way. The rest of the day I devoted to purchasing various products from Birmingham and to visiting some foundries and a steel casting factory, where I was very impressed by Mr. Hobday, engraver, from whom I had ordered various letters and stamps and who knows Mr. P., the owner of this factory, very well. I also visited another manufactory of the so-called new cast iron, of which the cast objects, such as wick trimmers, stirrups, all manner of carriage harness, etc., are as pliable as copper, and yet can be forged and hardened like steel, which is why it is also called, albeit incorrectly, “Cast-Steel”In diesem Werk begegnete Fischer zum ersten Mal dem hämmerbaren Gusseisen und dessen Herstellungsverfahren, dem Temperguss.. On account of their rarity, I bought not only a few unprocessed cast pieces, but also a dozen and a half very beautiful, if expensive, patented wick trimmers, which, when reopened,
leave neither the wick cuttings nor the foul odour behind. This transaction made me so agreeable to the manufacturer that he invited me to see his workshop and foundry. His only regret was that I, as a gentleman, could not have a proper understanding of the matter and consequently could not sufficiently appreciate the advantages of this method and the procedure to keep the cast iron completely pliable. I will only briefly note that the melting takes place in closed crucibles, in the same furnaces that are used in England for casting steel.

I had to wait a long time for Mr. P., who maintains the cast steel and cement steel factory and the furnaces for melting down the old iron in the same building. I was not displeased to wait, as it allowed me to explore at my leisure. His cement steel, which he later uses to make cast steel, and then only with
the usual English addition (which is why it is inferior and of inconsistent quality, especially since he only produces twenty pounds at a time), is made in a single chamber in a small furnace. I learned, however, that he is building a second plant to increase his output fourfold. Traditional iron smelting is done in a "Ball-Furnace", similar to "Puddling-Furnaces", but smaller. The rapidity with which the smelting is completed is remarkable, and if the process were only more generally known, it would have been taken to heart by many of the owners of works on the mainland, especially the rolling and cutting mills. In the latter, the lump that had been pounded under the heavy hammer was instantly transformed into the desired bars and rods.

div.head: Feilenmanufaktur und Reise nach Newcastle-under-Lyme, 31. August 1814
div.p:
On the morning of the 31st, I was to leave for
Newcastle-unter-Lide, which is only two miles west of Etruria, Wedgwood's famous factory. As the “Mail-Coatch” did not leave until ten o'clock, I made a quick visit to the rather remote file manufactory of Mr. P. As the supervisor or “Clark” had first to be awakened, I meanwhile ventured into the workshop where I saw the following, which may contribute a great deal to the perfection of the files. Firstly, all the files are forged under two hammers until they reach brown heat, and then they are given an indentation towards the centre of the entire length using a round, somewhat but only very slightly convex hammer on an equally convex anvil, whereby the corners become very sharp and very straight during grinding. The six grinding stones, powered by a steam engine were of coarse grain, but very
round and very even. Six very simple draft furnaces were used for annealing, which takes place in advance. The different strokes, in German called, "rauh, bastard and schlicht", are always made by the same workers. The two straps for securing the file are fixed more suitably than in our country and ensure reliable positioning on the point of the strike. A different technique is used for hammering in that the thumb is placed on the head of the hammer to ensure a safer stroke. The tempering is done by a single man. From the smell, and later upon inspection, I found that the powder used for tempering was one with which I am already familiar. It was very fine and mixed with brewer's yeast, which results in a more uniform coating of the file. The files were annealed one by one, then immersed slowly and vertically in water.
The crooked ones were returned to the fire and directed with a wooden stick on a trestle to the opposite side to straighten. — In England, the triangular saw files are never hewn with the upper cut, but only with a narrow lower cut, which gives a sharper and more durable corner. Incidentally, the files were not bad, but expensive according to the price quoted to me.

With some distress (having stayed so long) I returned just before the departure of the coach and boarded it at once. My traveling party consisted of an old Quaker from Liverpool and his grandson of about seventeen years, together with a worldling from Congleton. It did not require long to make the old man's acquaintance and, after I had given him sufficient information about the Jews
and pagans and the general Christian community of Schafhausen, he made quite clear his wish to see me admitted as a member of their brotherhood. He cordially invited me to come to his country estate, three miles from Liverpool, for eight or fourteen days, as he would only stay a few days at his own house in Sheffield, which he kept there only on account of his two ironworks. I politely declined this invitation but listened all the more attentively to a punitive sermon on drinking, something to which, he remarked, soldiers (of whom we encountered a great many in Walshale) were particularly devoted. Our traveling companion from Congleton did not take kindly to this. For, by his word, no true Englishman had any qualms about being sozzled, and only those with a bad
conscience, who wished to seem better than others, abstained from the drink. His crimson nose, a testimony to his own lack of moderation, was, incidentally, the clearest evidence that his words were sincere. Young Rye, the old man's grandson, however, despite his round low hat and plain “Drabcolour” coat (the brown colour of the cloth used for Quaker coats), was cleary not entirely free from the maladies of more worldly children. For a rather beautiful young woman, who at Wolverhampton, where we changed horses and stayed for a while, was standing at a window just opposite where the carriage was waiting, so captivated his attention that his eyeballs, as if he had had to look through two tubes, remained quite fixed. Upon observing this, the old man good-naturedly asked him to don his traveling cap
and, as the carriage was stationary, to sleep a while in its corner. However, as the effect on the young man of the object of his attention was anything but sedative, the old man’s admonishment was fruitless. — In the evening at six o'clock, we arrived at Castle-under-Lide, where I took leave of my good Quaker and his grandson and set out for my night's lodgings at the Wirthshaus zum Bock.

I had not been long in my room when it occurred to me to ask the landlord when a coach to Manchester would leave the following day. I returned downstairs to find him in the hallway. Without answer, however, he rushed past me and out the front door. I went after him, and behold, it was about a “Boxingmatch”, or fistfight, among four belligerent and drunken potters,
who were already stripped down in the square and had assumed a fighting posture, awaiting only the arrival of the high nobility of Newcastle and a sufficient number of spectators of the fair sex to begin the match, which soon took place. As they fought rather unskilfully, growing heartily annoyed by the irregularity of the blows on both sides, they soon became combatants in earnest and the maternal earth the theatre of their war. There they rolled about until two of the contenders, after having received a sufficient number of kicks and blows, no longer showed much inclination to get back up. Now that they were no longer able to harm one another, the constable, or justice of the peace, until then a silent spectator, ordered them with his long baton to make peace. As soon as they could walk and stand again, he took them all
into custody where they could rest on their laurels. He made one small mistake, however, having locked them all up together, so that after half an hour, as the fight began again, they cried bloody murder through the jail bars. Consequently, a complete separation of the parties was necessary, allowing them to contemplate their grievances and reflections of the night in undisturbed solitude.

Upon returning to my lodgings, I heard a cry from behind the door: Ah mon Dieu! est-ce qu’il n’y a personne ici, qui parle français? — I went up to the gentleman who had cried out and asked him in French if I could be of service to him in any way — Le bon Dieu nous nous envoye, he replied, nous sommes ici déja depuis midi (gesturing towards a woman standing next to him), et
malheureusement personne ne nous entend, et nous ne les entendons pas non plus. He then explained to me that he and his wife, both from Turin, had been in Manchester and, now, after having stopped in Etruria, wished to proceed to Birmingham, but that no one had understood them, nor had they accepted the money for the seats on the coach, which he had put down, making all manner of gestures. I returned with him to the “Post-Office”, where the clerk, a very decent fellow, told me that he had indeed understood that the couple wished to go to Birmingham, but that he had not taken their money because Newcastle, being the first stop, had no seats available, and that it all depended on whether the coach from Manchester was fully occupied. I explained
all of this to the man from Turin, and then, at his request, reserved the first vacant seats for the following day. — This incident shows how essential it is to understand something of the language if one wants to travel to England, as so few of the natives, especially among the common people (with whom one has the most contact during one's travels), speak any other language. This is also true of other nations, and only the Germans and Swiss make a praiseworthy exception in this respect.

While drinking tea and reading the newspaper (it was only a “Country-paper”), I was astonished to read under the header Schafhausen in Switzerland the news that Buonaparte had been brought from the island of Elba to Livorno, where he had stayed for twelve hours. It was not
the news itself but the connection of it with Schafhausen that astonished me.

div.head: In Wedgwoods Etruria Works, 1. September 1814
div.p:
Sobald ich den andern Morgen, als den 1. September, einen Platz in der Mail-Coatch nach Manchester, wohin sie Abends um vier Uhr abging, bestellt hatte, machte ich mich nach dem von Newcastle-under-Lide drei Meilen entlegenen Etruria auf den Weg. — Gerade wie bei Soho kommt man auch zuerst durch eine hübsche Strasse von Arbeiterwohnungen. Eiserne Rail-ways führen überall nach der ebenfalls an einem Kanal gelegenen Fabrik und darin herum. Als ich dem Hrn. Wedgwood, der bereits auf seinem Schreibzimmer war, meinen Brief von Hrn. Watt übergeben hatte, sagte er gleich: «Herr Fischer, wenn es Ihnen Vergnügen macht, die Fabrik zu sehen, so will ich Sie durch Jemand herumführen lassen, und dann kommen Sie wieder zu mir ins Wohnhaus und
nehmen ein Luncheon (was wir im Deutschen Morgen-Imbis nennen).» Ganz methodisch, das heisst, von dem primum mobile der Dampfmaschine an bis zur Aufbewahrung und Verpackung des fertigen Geschirrs, wurde mir nun auf Geheiss des Hrn. Wedgwood Alles gezeigt.

Unter einer Stampfe wird der aus der Gegend von Gravesand kommende Flint oder Kiesel, nachdem er gebrannt worden, gestampft, und dann auf Mühlen (den Glasurmühlen ähnlich, aber von sechs bis neun Fuss Durchmesser) gemahlen, welches auch mit der Pfeifenerde und den andern Thonarten der Fall ist. So wie dieses geschehen ist, erfolgt die Vermischung beider Stoffe zu gleichen Theilen, wo sie neuerdings in etwas kleinere Mühlen kommen, und mittelst viel hinzugegossenen Wassers in flüssiger Gestalt in Siebe (die aus den feinsten Seidenwurmfäden verfertigt
sind und durch Maschinerie beständig hin- und hergeschüttelt werden) laufen, um da durchzudringen, und so einen Grad von Feinheit erlangen, von dem man sich kaum einen Begriff machen kann, indem die Nähe der Fäden und ihre Dünne kein Partikel durchlässt, das nur den tausendsten Theil eines Zolls im Durchmesser hätte. Aus den untergestellten Gefässen wird nun die Masse auf die Trockenbetten gebracht. Sechszig Fuss lange, zwanzig Fuss breite und neun Zoll hohe, aus weichgebrannten Ziegelsteinen gebaute Gefässe sind es, unter welchen ein mildes Feuer unterhalten und die Masse darin beständig umgerührt wird, bis sie nach etwa vierundzwanzig Stunden so viel Bestand erhalten hat, dass sie nach den Zylindern gebracht werden kann. Diese Zylinder (uneigentlich aber so genannt, weil sie die Form abgestumpfter, auf dem dünnern Theil stehender Kegel haben) sind fünf Fuss
hoch, oben drei und unten zwei Fuss weit, mit einem an dem untern Theil rechtwinklicht ausgehenden kurzen Kanal von einem Fuss Breite und neun Zoll Höhe versehen. Durch diese Zylinder oder Coni hinunter geht eine eiserne Achse, die durch Räderwerk getrieben wird, und an der sich der Länge nach hinunter spiralförmig die sogenannten Messer befinden, die, weil sie flach liegen und mit ihren Enden den Conus fast berühren, von oben herunter gesehen eine Art von Schneckengewinde bilden, welches den von Zeit zu Zeit oben hineingeworfenen Thon fasst, hinunternimmt und durch das am Ende befindliche Loch hinauspresst, wo er immer nach und nach mit einem Drath zu viereckigen Klötzen abgeschnitten und auf einen Haufen nebenbei geschlagen wird. Nach einer drei- bis viertägigen Fermentation, oder vielmehr gleichförmigen Durchfeuchtung, kommt er noch
einmal in die Zylinder, und wird wieder zu Klötzen von vorbeschriebener Form gestaltet, auf Brettern den Arbeitern zugetragen. Es ist hier der Ort, zu sagen, dass die Rail-ways oder eisernen Strassen, die in der ganzen Fabrik herumgehen, hauptsächlich zum Transport der Materien gebraucht werden, der auf eisernen, mit offenen Kasten versehenen kleinen Wagen geschieht. Ein solcher Wagen wird von einem einzigen Mann geschoben, und wiegt sammt der Ladung 1320 Pfund, welches mir, um mich davon zu überzeugen, vorgewogen wurde.

Die gemeine Töpferscheibe ist nun das Werkzeug, auf welcher der zur Verarbeitung fertige Thon (mit Ausnahme der flachen Teller, von deren Bereitung ich später reden werde) seine erste Bildung erhält. In zwei Dingen nur unterscheidet sie sich von der unserigen: nämlich dass sie, zur Verhütung des Krumm
ziehens, von Mahagony ist, und dass sie nicht durch Menschen, sondern durch Maschinenkräfte bewegt wird, welches die Arbeit ungemein erleichtert und das Produkt in gleicher Zeit beinahe verdoppelt.

Bei dieser Gelegenheit sah ich eine der sinnreichsten und einfachsten Einrichtungen, um der Töpferscheibe augenblicklich schnellere oder langsamere Bewegung ertheilen zu können, obgleich die Dampfmaschine, wie leicht zu erachten, ihren steten und gleichen Gang fortgeht. Zwei hohle Coni nämlich, wovon der eine statt der Rolle an der Achse oder Spindel der Scheibe, der andere aber in umgekehrter Stellung, das heisst die Basis oben, in einer Entfernung von zwölf Zoll zwischen zwei Kolben befestigt ist, bilden das Treibende und das Getriebene mittelst eines um beide herumgeschlungenen ledernen Riemens. Eine an einem Tritt befestigte eiserne
Gabel führt nach dem Willen des Arbeiters den Riemen augenblicklich nach oben oder unten, wo dann in dem ersten Fall die Scheibe langsam, im andern aber sehr geschwind herumlauft, wenn schon der Parallelismus der Seitenflächen der Coni und folglich die Anspannung des Riemens immer gleich bleibt. Dieselbe sinnreiche Einrichtung besteht auch bei den Drehstühlen, von denen ich weiter unten reden werde.

Von den Scheiben weg kommen die Gefässe in die Trockenstuben, wo sie bei einer Temperatur von achtzig Grad Reaum. in Kurzem einen Bestand erlangen, der etwas mehr ist, als was die Hafner bei uns wasserhart nennen. In diesem Zustand, da sie steif genug sind, um damit ohne Gefahr des Verbiegens umgehen zu können, kommen sie auf die horizontalen Drehstühle, wo die Art des Einspannens auf und in hölzerne Futter oder
Patronen sehr einfach und sicher ist. Das einzige Werkzeug zum Drehen ist eine dünne, verschiedenartig gebogene Schabklinge, die, wann das Geschirr fertig gedreht ist, auch zum Poliren gebraucht wird, welches bei der so äusserst feinen Masse auffallend schön erfolgt. Ist das Geschirr nachher so hart, dass es in den Ofen gebracht werden kann, so kommt es in die von feuerfestem grobem Thon nach den verschiedenen Grössen der Gefässe bereiteten Casetten. Hier bemerkte ich etwas, das ausser England vielleicht nicht bekannt und doch von äusserster Wichtigkeit ist, um das Krummziehen, besonders der Teller und Platten, zu verhüten.
